results.title: EXCISE TAX ON REPURCHASE OF CORPORATE STOCK
results.content: Section 10201. EXCISE TAX ON REPURCHASE OF CORPORATE STOCK.... FUNDING THE INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE AND IMPROVING TAXPAYER COMPLIANCE
results.summary: This section amends Subtitle D to impose a 1% tax on repurchased corporate stock in domestic and applicable foreign corporations. Exceptions exist for specific repurchase cases.
key_points: 1% tax imposed on repurchased stock of domestic corporations and applicable foreign corporations
Specific exceptions are provided for certain contexts in which stock is repurchased
Applicable to repurchases of stock done after December 31, 2022

defined_terms.covered corporation: any domestic corporation the stock of which is traded on an established securities market
defined_terms.repurchase: A redemption within the meaning of section 317(b) with regard to the stock of a covered corporation
defined_terms.specified affiliate: corporation or partnership where more than 50% of stock/capital interests or profits interests are owned by the corporation
defined_terms.applicable foreign corporation: any foreign corporation the stock of which is traded on an established securities market
defined_terms.covered surrogate foreign corporation: surrogate foreign corporation with stock traded on the established securities market

impacts.description: This law would impose additional costs onto corporations that choose to repurchase their stock, potentially discouraging this practice. It would primarily impact corporations with significant stock repurchase programs.
impacts.estimated_cost: 1% of the cost of each stock repurchase
impacts.timeline: Effective from January 1, 2023

results.title: CORPORATE ALTERNATIVE MINIMUM TAX
results.content: Section 10101...PART 2--EXCISE TAX ON REPURCHASE OF CORPORATE STOCK
results.summary: This section reinstates a Corporate Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT) and adjusts its calculations. Corporations that clear an adjusted financial statement income test get subjected to a 15% AMT, while other corporations' tentative minimum tax would be zero. Adjustments are made for corporations with short taxable years, those undergoing a change in ownership, and those part of a multinational group with a foreign parent. The tax applies from December 31, 2022, onwards.
key_points: Reinstatement of a Corporate Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT) of 15% for defined 'applicable corporations'.
Introduction of a financial statement income test for corporate entities to determine who the tax applies to.
New rules for corporations under multinational groups with a foreign parent.
Inclusion of provisions to account for corporations that haven't been in existence for three years or less.
Provisions to adjust for corporations that have undergone a change in ownership.

defined_terms.applicable corporation: Any corporation (excluding S corps, regulated investment companies, or REITs) meeting a certain average annual adjusted financial statement income test.

impacts.description: Reinstating the corporate AMT would increase tax liabilities for applicable corporations, potentially impacting profitability and shareholders' earnings.
impacts.timeline: Effective from December 31, 2022

referenced_sections: 21(c) of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act

results.title: ENHANCEMENT OF INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE RESOURCES
results.content: Section 10301. ENHANCEMENT OF INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE RESOURCES....[TRUNCATED FOR BREVITY]...
results.summary: This section of the bill details a significant increase in funding for the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) and various subsets of the Treasury Department. Additionally, it calls for the development of a task force aiming to create a free 'direct efile' tax return system.
key_points: Approximately $79 billion is allocated to various IRS services, including taxpayer services, tax enforcement activities, operations support, and business systems modernization.
$15 million is assigned to develop a report on the feasibility of a free 'direct efile' tax return system.
Specific funds are also provided to the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration, Office of Tax Policy, United States Tax Court, and Departmental Offices of the Department of the Treasury.
Funds will remain available until September 30, 2031, with the exception of the task force studying the direct efile system, which has a deadline of September 30, 2023.

defined_terms.direct efile tax return system: A proposed free tax filing system run by the Internal Revenue Service.

impacts.description: Significant impact on the treasury due to appropriation of large funds. The IRS will likely boost its services, undergo systems modernization, and explore the feasibility of a free direct efile system. Additionally, other sectors of the Treasury Department will receive increased funding.
impacts.estimated_cost: $79,353,600,000 to the IRS, $15,000,000 to direct efile task force, $403,000,000 to the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration, $104,533,803 to Office of Tax Policy, $153,000,000 to the United States Tax Court, $50,000,000 to the Departmental Offices of the Department of the Treasury
impacts.timeline: Funding to remain available until September 30, 2031. The task force studying the direct efile system has a shorter deadline of September 30, 2023.

results.title: SPECIAL RULE TO DELAY SELECTION AND NEGOTIATION OF BIOLOGICS FOR BIOSIMILAR MARKET ENTRY
results.content: Section 11002...
results.summary: Section 11002 details the procedures and conditions under which the inclusion of a biological drug in a published list for biosimilar market entry can be delayed. This includes scenarios where a biosimilar biological product is expected to be licensed within a two-year timeframe after the list's publication. It also regulates the process of requesting said delay, additional information requirements, and limitations on delays. Furthermore, it establishes consequences when the biosimilar product is not licensed and marketed during the delay.
key_points: New rules explain how and when the selection of biological products for biosimilar market entry could be delayed.
Provisions for manufacturers to request a delay, involving the submission and review of related documents and information.
Explains the consequences of failing to market the biosimilar product during the delay, including payment of rebates.
Specific limitations on delays and conditions regarding their applicability.

defined_terms.high likelihood: An accepted or approved application for licensure for the biosimilar biological product, as well as clear evidence that the product will be marketed within a specific timeframe.

impacts.description: Biological drug manufacturers will have the ability to request a delay in inclusion on the selection list, potentially affecting market entry strategies. Customers might face delayed access to certain drugs, while competing pharmaceutical companies might have to adjust their strategies.
impacts.timeline: Implementation for 2026 through 2028

results.title: EXCISE TAX IMPOSED ON DRUG MANUFACTURERS DURING NONCOMPLIANCE PERIODS
results.content: Section 11003...
results.summary: This section introduces an excise tax on pharmaceutical manufacturers who do not comply with drug pricing regulations. The tax amounts vary based on the duration of noncompliance.
key_points: Pharmaceutical manufacturers will face an excise tax during noncompliance periods
The tax rate escalates with the duration of noncompliance. Starts at 65% for the first 90 days and may reach up to 95% for subsequent days
Noncompliance periods relate to specific events in the drug pricing negotiation and agreement process under different clauses of the Social Security Act

defined_terms.Designated drug: Any negotiation-eligible drug (as defined in section 1192(d) of the Social Security Act) included on the list published under section 1192(a) of such Act which is manufactured or produced in the United States or entered into the United States for consumption, use, or warehousing

impacts.description: Significant impact on manufacturers who don't comply with drug pricing regulations due to new excise tax. Could potentially lead to higher drug prices or increased pressure to comply with pricing regulations.
impacts.timeline: Effective immediately upon sales after the enactment of this Act

results.title: MEDICARE PART B REBATE BY MANUFACTURERS
results.content: Section 11101. MEDICARE PART B REBATE BY MANUFACTURERS....full section text included here.........
results.summary: This section amends the Social Security Act to require manufacturers to provide a rebate for Medicare Part B 'rebatable drugs' where their prices increase faster than inflation. The amount of the rebate would be calculated based on specific terms and factors included in the section. It also dictates how and when the rebates must be provided by manufacturers, and establishes penalties for non-compliance.
key_points: Prescribes a manufacturer requirement to provide a rebate for Medicare Part B 'rebatable drugs' whose prices increase faster than inflation.
Outlines the calculation process for the rebate based on total number of units and excess average sales price increase.
Provides a transition rule allowing for delayed reporting of information in 2023 and 2024.
Establishes limitations on administrative or judicial review of determinations made under this subsection.
Includes a penalty for manufacturers who fail to comply.

defined_terms.part B rebatable drug: A 'single source drug' or 'biological', including a 'biosimilar biological product' except 'qualifying biosimilar biological product', for which payment is made under this part.

impacts.description: This requirement could lead to reduced drug prices over time for Medicare Part B because manufacturers may choose to limit price increases to avoid the rebate requirement. This could result in cost savings for beneficiaries and government reimbursement programs.
impacts.estimated_cost: No specific cost provided but further costs will be expected to be covered by rebates from manufacturers.
impacts.timeline: It begins with the end of each calendar quarter from January 1, 2023, and manufacturers should provide the rebate no later than 30 days after the receipt of the information from the Secretary. Rebate rule would start applying to beneficiary coinsurance from April 1, 2023.
affected_groups: Healthcare providers offering Medicare Part B

referenced_sections: Section 1847A of the Social Security Act

funding_amounts.Operational Costs: An additional $80,000,000 for fiscal year 2022, including $12,500,000 for implementing the provisions of this section in 2022, and $7,500,000 for each of fiscal years 2023 through 2031, to remain available until expended.

results.title: MEDICARE PART D REBATE BY MANUFACTURERS
results.content: Section 11102. MEDICARE PART D REBATE BY MANUFACTURERS... (text truncated for brevity)...
results.summary: This section amends Part D of Title XVIII of the Social Security Act to include a new rebate system for certain drugs whose prices increase faster than inflation. It stipulates that manufacturers of these part D rebatable drugs must provide to the Secretary a rebate that matches the excess annual manufacturer price increase. The section also sets rules for calculating this rebate and penalties for non-compliance.
key_points: Introduces new manufacturer rebate system for certain drugs under Medicare Part D.
Rebate amount calculated based on manufacturer's price increase faster than inflation.
Details processes and timelines for reporting of information on drug prices and rebate amounts.
Stipulates penalties for non-compliance, including civil money penalties equal to 125% of the rebate amount.

defined_terms.part D rebatable drug: With respect to an applicable period, a drug or biological that is a covered part D drug
defined_terms.applicable period: A 12-month period beginning with October 1 of a year (beginning with October 1, 2022)
defined_terms.payment amount benchmark period: The period beginning January 1, 2021, and ending in the month immediately prior to October 1, 2021

impacts.description: This would impose significant financial obligations on drug manufacturers, which might adjust their pricing strategies to mitigate the impacts of these rebates.
impacts.estimated_cost: Depends on the number and sales volume of part D rebatable drugs
impacts.timeline: Effective from October 1, 2022

impacts.description: Could potentially help slow the growth of prescription drug prices, making them more affordable for consumers, particularly for those enrolled in Medicare Part D
impacts.timeline: Impacts become evident starting October 1, 2022
affected_groups: Individuals enrolled in Medicare Part D

funding_amounts.Implementation of provisions in fiscal y: $80,000,000, including $12,500,000 in fiscal year 2022, and $7,500,000 in each of fiscal years 2023 through 2031

results.title: MAXIMUM MONTHLY CAP ON COST-SHARING PAYMENTS UNDER PRESCRIPTION DRUG PLANS AND MA-PD PLANS
results.content: [Full section 11202 text provided in prompt]
results.summary: This section amends the Social Security Act and introduces a new cost-sharing payment structure for enrollees in Prescription Drug Plans (PDPs) and Medication Assistance-Prescription Drug (MA-PD) plans. A maximum monthly cap is set for cost-sharing payments starting from 2025, with various operational details provided. The section also appropriates $10 million for fiscal year 2023 to implement this change.
key_points: Introduction of a maximum monthly cap on cost-sharing payments under prescription drug and MA-PD plans for plan years starting from January 1, 2025.
Provision for enrollees to elect to pay cost-sharing in capped monthly amounts.
Enrollees can elect to make such a decision prior to the start of the plan year or in any month during the plan year.
Failure to pay the amount billed will result in the termination of the election.
This section appropriates $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2023 to implement the amendments.

defined_terms.maximum monthly cap: A limit set on the cost-sharing payments made per month by an enrollee. Determined by the annual out-of-pocket threshold, other incurred costs, and the remaining months of the plan year.
defined_terms.PDP sponsor: An entity offering a prescription drug plan.
defined_terms.MA organization: An entity offering a Medication Assistance-Prescription Drug (MA-PD) plan.

impacts.description: PDP and MA-PD plan operators will undergo substantial changes to their cost-sharing structures, potentially affecting their revenue. Enrollees may see their monthly costs become more predictable and manageable, which could improve medication adherence rates.
impacts.timeline: Provisions apply to plan years starting on or after January 1, 2025; funding allocated in fiscal year 2023.
affected_groups: Enrollees in PDPs and MA-PD plans

results.title: Coverage of Adult Vaccines Recommended by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices under Medicare Part D
results.content: Section 11401. COVERAGE OF ADULT VACCINES RECOMMENDED BY THE ADVISORY...
results.summary: This section amends the Social Security Act to provide consistent coverage, through Medicare Part D, for adult vaccines that are recommended by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices. These vaccines will be are not subject to deductible and there will be no cost-sharing. The implementation of this provision begins from January 1, 2023.
key_points: Coverage of adult vaccines recommended by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices under Medicare Part D.
No deductible or other cost-sharing for these vaccines, starting from plan year 2023.
Provision of a temporary retrospective subsidy for the reduction in cost-sharing and deductible for such vaccines during 2023.
Coverage under Part D of the Social Security Act for vaccines that are not recommended by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices remains unchanged.

defined_terms.Adult vaccines recommended by the Adviso: a covered part D drug that is a vaccine licensed under section 351 of the Public Health Service Act for use by adult populations and administered in accordance with recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices

impacts.description: This provision will increase the coverage for adult vaccines under Medicare Part D, reducing costs for beneficiaries. The provision will likely lead to higher vaccine rates which could decrease healthcare costs in the long term.
impacts.estimated_cost: Cost would depend on uptake of vaccines, projected to be in millions.
impacts.timeline: Effective from January 1, 2023

funding_amounts.Temporary retrospective subsidy for the: Amount equal to the aggregate reduction in cost-sharing and deductible

results.title: EXTENSION OF MORATORIUM ON IMPLEMENTATION OF RULE RELATING TO ELIMINATING THE ANTI-KICKBACK STATUTE SAFE HARBOR PROTECTION FOR PRESCRIPTION DRUG REBATES
results.content: Section 11301. EXTENSION OF MORATORIUM ON IMPLEMENTATION OF RULE RELATING TO ELIMINATING THE ANTI-KICKBACK STATUTE SAFE HARBOR PROTECTION FOR PRESCRIPTION DRUG REBATES. The Secretary of Health and Human Services shall not, prior to January 1, 2032, implement, administer, or enforce the provisions of the final rule published by the Office of the Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services on November 30, 2020, and titled ``Fraud and Abuse; Removal of Safe Harbor Protection for Rebates Involving Prescription Pharmaceuticals and Creation of New Safe Harbor Protection for Certain Point-of-Sale Reductions in Price on Prescription Pharmaceuticals and Certain Pharmacy Benefit Manager Service Fees'' (85 Fed. Reg. 76666). PART 5--MISCELLANEOUS
results.summary: This section extends the moratorium on implementing a rule that would eliminate a statutory protection against legal backlash for pharmaceutical companies providing rebates. This moratorium is extended until January 1, 2032.
key_points: Moratorium on implementation of a rule relating to the anti-kickback statute safe harbor protection is extended until January 1, 2032.

impacts.description: Pharmaceutical companies, pharmacy benefit managers, and potentially patients (due to the effect on drug pricing) may be impacted by this extended moratorium. The impact is significant due to the potential risks and penalties involved in rebate practices.
impacts.timeline: Effective until January 1, 2032

results.title: PAYMENT FOR BIOSIMILAR BIOLOGICAL PRODUCTS DURING INITIAL PERIOD
results.content: Section 11402. PAYMENT FOR BIOSIMILAR BIOLOGICAL PRODUCTS DURING INITIAL PERIOD. Section 1847A(c)(4) of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1395w- 3a(c)(4)) is amended-- (1) in each of subparagraphs (A) and (B), by redesignating clauses (i) and (ii) as subclauses (I) and (II), respectively, and moving such subclauses 2 ems to the right;...
results.summary: This section amends Section 1847A(c)(4) of the Social Security Act, focusing on the payment of biosimilar biological products during the initial period. It limits the amount payable for a biosimilar biological product furnished after July 1, 2024, either to the amount determined for the biosimilar biological product or for the reference biological product.
key_points: Redesignation of clauses and subclauses in Section 1847A(c)(4) of the Social Security Act.
Establishment of limitation on payment amount for biosimilar biological products.
Payment amount is based on either the value of the biosimilar product or its reference biological product.

impacts.description: This amendment will likely substantially impact bio-pharmaceutical manufacturers by potentially reducing revenue from biosimilar products after July 1, 2024.
impacts.timeline: Effective from 1 July 2024.

results.title: TEMPORARY INCREASE IN MEDICARE PART B PAYMENT FOR CERTAIN BIOSIMILAR BIOLOGICAL PRODUCTS
results.content: Section 11403. TEMPORARY INCREASE IN MEDICARE PART B PAYMENT FOR CERTAIN BIOSIMILAR BIOLOGICAL PRODUCTS. Section 1847A(b)(8) of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1395w- 3a(b)(8)) is amended.........
results.summary: Section 11403 allows for a temporary increased Medicare Part B payment of 8% (up from the previous 6%) for certain qualifying biosimilar biological products for a duration of five years.
key_points: Payments for qualifying biosimilar biological products that are furnished during an applicable five-year period are increased.
The existing 6% rate is replaced with an 8% rate during that period.
A qualifying biosimilar biological product is defined as one where the average sales price isn’t more than the average sales price of its reference product.

defined_terms.qualifying biosimilar biological product: A biosimilar biological product described in paragraph (1)(C) with respect to which the average sales price is not more than the average sales price for the reference biological product

impacts.description: This section might result in lower costs for patients on medicare that are prescribed certain qualifying biosimilar biological products. It could also incentivize the increased production of these products due to the higher Medicare payment rate.
impacts.timeline: Starts from October 1, 2022, and persists for a period of 5 years.

results.title: EXPANDING ELIGIBILITY FOR LOW-INCOME SUBSIDIES UNDER PART D OF THE MEDICARE PROGRAM
results.content: Section 11404. EXPANDING ELIGIBILITY FOR LOW-INCOME SUBSIDIES UNDER PART D OF THE MEDICARE PROGRAM. Section 1860D-14(a) of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1395w- 114(a)), as amended by sections 11201 and 11401, is amended--[full content continues...]
results.summary: This section amends the Social Security Act to raise the income threshold for low-income Medicare Part D beneficiaries. The amendment increases the income limit to 150% (from the initial 135%) for individuals to be eligible for certain subsidies, effective from January 1, 2024.
key_points: Amends Section 1860D-14(a) of the Social Security Act to increase the income limit for certain low-income individuals for subsidy eligibility
The income limit changes from 135% to 150%
Change in eligibility criteria effective January 1, 2024

impacts.description: Expanding eligibility for low-income subsidies under Part D of Medicare will increase the number of individuals who can access these subsidies. This will likely increase costs for the Medicare program, but can also improve prescription drug affordability for low-income seniors.
impacts.timeline: Effective from January 1, 2024

results.title: IMPROVING ACCESS TO ADULT VACCINES UNDER MEDICAID AND CHIP
results.content: Section 11405. IMPROVING ACCESS TO ADULT VACCINES UNDER MEDICAID AND CHIP...(full section text)...
results.summary: This section changes the Social Security Act to require the coverage of adult vaccines under Medicaid and CHIP, prohibits cost-sharing for these vaccines, and increases federal assistance for their provision. Vaccine coverage and administration will also be required for certain groups under state plans or waiver plans. The amendments this section introduces will take effect on the first day of the first fiscal quarter that begins a year after the law's enactment.
key_points: Mandatory inclusion of adult vaccines in Medicaid and CHIP.
Prohibition of cost-sharing for these vaccines.
Increase of federal medical assistance percentage for vaccine-related costs
The changes will apply to expenditures made under state plans or waiver of such plans for Medicaid or CHIP.

impacts.description: The section could greatly increase vaccine access for adults under Medicaid and CHIP, potentially leading to higher vaccination rates and improved public health.
impacts.timeline: Effective from the first fiscal quarter that begins 1 year after the law's enactment
affected_groups: Adults eligible for Medicaid and CHIP
States administering Medicaid and CHIP programs

funding_amounts.Improved vaccine access under Medicaid a: Federal medical assistance percentage increased by 1 percentage point for first 8 fiscal quarters after the effective date

results.title: LIMITATION ON MONTHLY COINSURANCE AND ADJUSTMENTS TO SUPPLIER PAYMENT UNDER MEDICARE PART B FOR INSULIN FURNISHED THROUGH DURABLE MEDICAL EQUIPMENT
results.content: Section 11407. LIMITATION ON MONTHLY COINSURANCE AND ADJUSTMENTS TO SUPPLIER PAYMENT UNDER MEDICARE PART B FOR INSULIN FURNISHED THROUGH DURABLE MEDICAL EQUIPMENT. ...
results.summary: This section amends the Social Security Act to limit the amount of monthly coinsurance paid by individuals for insulin supplied through durable medical equipment under Medicare Part B to $35, effective from July 1, 2023.
key_points: Waives the Medicare Part B deductible for insulin supplied via durable medical equipment from July 1, 2023.
Limits patient coinsurance for insulin to $35 per month.
Allows Secretary of Health and Human Services to adjust supplier payments.

defined_terms.Coinsurance: A type of cost sharing where costs are split on a percentage basis between the insurance provider and the insured individual
defined_terms.Durable medical equipment: Equipment used in home health care like walkers, wheelchairs, or hospital beds

impacts.description: The amendments in this section could significantly reduce out-of-pocket expenses for insulin-dependent Medicare Part B enrollees, benefiting particularly those who use durable medical equipment for their insulin administration. However, it may potentially impact the revenues of suppliers due to the possible adjustments to supplier payments.
impacts.timeline: Effective from July 1, 2023

results.title: APPROPRIATE COST-SHARING FOR COVERED INSULIN PRODUCTS UNDER MEDICARE PART D
results.content: Section 11406. APPROPRIATE COST-SHARING FOR COVERED INSULIN PRODUCTS UNDER MEDICARE PART D... [truncated for brevity]
results.summary: This section establishes the terms of cost-sharing for insulin products under Medicare Part D for plan years starting from 2023. It stipulates that the deductible does not apply to covered insulin products and establishes the cost-sharing ranges for these products until 2026. It also appropriates $1.5 million to Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services for implementation.
key_points: No deductibles will be applied to covered insulin products starting in 2023
The cost-sharing amount for a month's supply of insulin is set to not exceed $35 for plan years 2023, 2024, and 2025
From 2026, the cost-sharing for insulin becomes the lesser of $35, 25% of the maximum fair price, and 25% of the negotiated price
Provision of a special reimbursement rule for the first three months of 2023
The plan provides additional funding to implement these changes

defined_terms.covered insulin product: An insulin product that is a covered part D drug covered under the prescription drug plan or MA-PD plan that is approved under section 505 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act or licensed under section 351 of the Public Health Service Act and marketed pursuant to such approval or licensure
defined_terms.applicable copayment amount: Cost-sharing amount set for different plan years for a covered insulin product

impacts.description: Significantly reduces financial barriers for Medicare Part D enrollees to access insulin products by capping cost-sharing and eliminating deductibles
impacts.timeline: Effective from plan year 2023

Section 13001. AMENDMENT OF 1986 CODE.

results.summary: This section stipulates that all amendments or repeals in this subtitle which are expressed in terms of amendments to or repeals of sections or provisions should be interpreted as referring to sections or provisions of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
key_points: All amendments or repeals in this subtitle expressed in terms of amendments or repeals refer to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
This interpretation applies unless there is explicit provision otherwise.

impacts.description: This section mainly affects the interpretation and application of the sections in this subtitle, and as such, its impact is largely procedural. It potentially affects all sectors as it will guide how the amendments and repeals in this subtitle are interpreted and applied.
impacts.timeline: Effective upon passage
affected_groups: All sectors affected by this bill

results.title: EXTENSION AND MODIFICATION OF CREDIT FOR ELECTRICITY PRODUCED FROM CERTAIN RENEWABLE RESOURCES
results.content:
Section 13101. EXTENSION AND MODIFICATION OF CREDIT FOR ELECTRICITY...
(h) Credit Reduced for Tax-exempt Bonds.--Section 45(b)(3) is amended...
(j) Hydropower.-- (1) Elimination of credit rate reduction for qualified hydroelectric production...
(k) Effective Dates.-- (1) In general.--Except as provided...
results.summary: Section 13101 of the bill extends and modifies a renewable energy tax credit, reducing it from 1.5 cents to 0.3 cents. This applies to electricity produced from certain renewable resources like wind, geothermal, and solar energy. The section also sets out additional requirements regarding wage and apprenticeship programs that need to be fulfilled by qualified facilities. New rules in domestic content, phaseout, and energy communities are also set for the qualified facilities.
key_points: The tax credit for electricity produced from certain renewable resources extended to January 1, 2025 and reduced from 1.5 cents to 0.3 cents.
New wage, apprenticeship and domestic content requirements instituted for candidates to receive the credit.
Evident increase to credit under certain circumstances such including when the construction of facilities happens in energy communities.

defined_terms.qualified facility: a facility which fulfills various requirements including those set for apprenticeship, wage, domestic content and being in an energy community.

impacts.description: The provision incentivizes further investment in renewable energy sector by extending the tax credit. However, the reduction in credit rate and imposition of additional requirements might impact the economic feasibility for some stakeholders.
impacts.estimated_cost: Increase in production costs from compliance with the new rules
impacts.timeline: Effective from facilities placed in service after December 31, 2021 with different impacts depending on specific date a qualified facility's construction begins.
affected_groups: workers/wage earners in the renewable energy sector

results.title: EXTENSION AND MODIFICATION OF ENERGY CREDIT
results.content:
Section 13102. EXTENSION AND MODIFICATION OF ENERGY CREDIT...
...
results.summary: This section extends and modifies the tax credits related to energy property. It adjusts the dates and percentages of various credits, introduces new qualified categories, and phases out others. Importantly, it introduces an increased credit for projects within an energy community and that comply with wage and apprenticeship requirements. The modifications take effect at different points in time.
key_points: The tax credit termination dates on several subsections of section 48 are pushed forward.
Additional extensions are applied to certain energy property, and a phaseout is introduced for qualified fuel cell property, small wind property, or energy property as per clauses in the bill.
The energy percentage for energy projects is adjusted, moving from 30% to 6% for some properties and from 10% to 2% for others.
New categories of energy property, including energy storage technology, qualified biogas property, and microgrid controllers, are introduced.
Credit rate increases are established for projects within an energy community and those that comply with wage and apprenticeship requirements.

defined_terms.energy project: a project consisting of one or more energy properties that are part of a single project

impacts.description: The extension, phaseouts, and modifications of the energy credits could incentivize investment and advancements in various energy sectors, supporting construction jobs and renewable energy development. The addition of new technologies (like energy storage and microgrids) could impact R&D and deployment in these fields. Energy companies who plan their production around these credits may need to adjust their strategies.
impacts.estimated_cost: Dependent on the size and quantity of projects that receive credits
impacts.timeline: Most changes are effective for properties placed in service after December 31, 2021. Other changes take effect for properties placed in service after December 31, 2022. The amendment related to tax-exempt bonds applies to properties whose construction begins after enactment.

results.title: INCREASE IN ENERGY CREDIT FOR SOLAR AND WIND FACILITIES PLACED IN SERVICE IN CONNECTION WITH LOW-INCOME COMMUNITIES
results.content: Section 13103. INCREASE IN ENERGY CREDIT FOR SOLAR AND WIND FACILITIES PLACED IN SERVICE... (b) Effective Date.--The amendments made by this section shall take effect on January 1, 2023.
results.summary: Section 13103 introduces an increase in the energy credit for solar and wind facilities that are placed in service in connection with low-income communities. This credit increase would apply to facilities meeting specific criteria, including a maximum net output below 5 megawatts and situated within specific geographic areas or serving low-income populations. The section also introduces mechanisms for allocating and recapturing this additional credit.
key_points: Increase in energy credit for solar and wind facilities is allocated depending on the facility's relationship with low-income communities.
Facilities are qualified based on their generation capability, power output, and location or the population they serve.
The Secretary must establish a program for allocating these additional credits within 180 days after the enactment of this subsection.
Mechanisms for recapturing the benefit of the credit increase are outlined.

defined_terms.qualified solar and wind facility: A facility generating electricity solely from certain property, with a maximum net output below 5 megawatts, and located either in a low-income community, on Indian land, or as part of a qualified low-income residential building project or economic benefit project.

results.title: ZERO-EMISSION NUCLEAR POWER PRODUCTION CREDIT.
results.content: Section 13105...
results.summary: Introduces a zero-emission nuclear power production credit that adds to the Energy Tax Credits based on each kilowatt hour of electricity produced by a qualified nuclear power facility and sold. The credit amount would be 0.3 cents per kilowatt hour, adjusted for inflation.
key_points: Introduces Zero-Emission Nuclear Power Production Credit.
Credit equal to 0.3 cents multiplied by each kilowatt hour produced and sold by taxpayer at a qualified nuclear power facility.
The credit reduces if certain existed subsidies are received from zero-emission credit programs.
Credit is increased by up to five times for facilities adhering to certain wage requirements.
Provisions of the credit cease to apply past the year ending December 31, 2032.

defined_terms.qualified nuclear power facility: A nuclear facility owned by the taxpayer, using nuclear energy to produce electricity, not defined as an advanced nuclear power facility under subsection (d)(1) of section 45J and placed in service before the enactment of this section.
defined_terms.electricity: The energy produced by a qualified nuclear power facility from the conversion of nuclear fuel into electric power.
defined_terms.reduction amount: The lesser of the amount determined under subsection (a)(1) or an amount calculated based on 16 percent of the excess of gross receipts from any electricity produced and sold by the qualified nuclear power facility.

impacts.description: Benefits nuclear power companies by offering a taxed credit for each electricity unit produced and sold, with the possibility of credit multiplication with the meeting of certain wage requirements. This provides a financial advantage to nuclear power producers and may foster the production of nuclear power.

Introduction of wage and apprenticeship requirements for increased credit eligibility
A reduction in credit for facilities using tax-exempt bonds
Specifications for carbon capture equipment in disaster-affected areas and consequent credit calculations
Regulations for adjusting baseline carbon oxide production

impacts.description: Incentivizes carbon capture, positively affecting climate change mitigation efforts.

results.title: IMPROVE AFFORDABILITY AND REDUCE PREMIUM COSTS OF HEALTH INSURANCE FOR CONSUMERS
results.content: Section 12001. IMPROVE AFFORDABILITY AND REDUCE PREMIUM COSTS OF HEALTH INSURANCE FOR CONSUMERS. (b) Extension Through 2025 of Rule to Allow Credit to Taxpayers Whose Household Income Exceeds 400 Percent of the Poverty Line.-- Section 36B(c)(1)(E) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended-- (1) by striking ``in 2021 or 2022'' and inserting ``after December 31, 2020, and before January 1, 2026'', and (2) by striking ``2021 and 2022'' in the heading and inserting ``2021 through 2025''. (c) Effective Date.--The amendments made by this section shall apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2022. Subtitle D--Energy Security
results.summary: Section 12001 amends IRS code 36B(b)(3)(A) and 36B(c)(1)(E), extending the credit allowed to taxpayers whose household income exceeds 400% of the poverty line through 2025, and expanding the rule's applicability from 2021-2022 to 2021-2025. key_points: Extension of taxpayers' credit rule through to 2025
Credits allowed to taxpayers whose household income exceeds 400% of the poverty line
Sections of the IRS code—36B(b)(3)(A) and 36B(c)(1)(E)—are amended
Amendments effective for tax years beginning after December 31, 2022

results.title: EXTENSION OF SECOND GENERATION BIOFUEL INCENTIVES
results.content:

Extension from 2022 to 2025
Amendment applies to biofuel production after December 31, 2021

results.title: SUSTAINABLE AVIATION FUEL CREDIT
results.content: Section 13203...fuel sold or used after December 31, 2022.
results.summary: Sections 13203 introduces a credit for the sale or use of sustainable aviation fuel identified as a 'qualified mixture.' The credit consists of $1.25 per gallon of fuel plus an additional $0.01 for each percentage point by which the fuel reduces lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions beyond 50%, up to a maximum of $0.50. The section defines key terms related to this credit and sets conditions for being a sustainable aviation fuel producer. The credit takes effect from January 1, 2023, and ends on December 31, 2024.
key_points: Introduction of a sustainable aviation fuel credit
Credit consists of a base rate plus a supplementary amount based on reduced greenhouse gas emissions
Credit applies per gallon of sustainable aviation fuel within a qualified mixture
Producer certification and registration requirements
Credit only applies to fuel sold or used after December 31, 2022 and before January 1, 2025

defined_terms.Applicable Supplementary Amount: an additional credit equal to $0.01 for each percentage point by which the lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions reduction percentage of the sustainable aviation fuel exceeds 50%, capped at $0.50
defined_terms.Qualified Mixture: a mixture of sustainable aviation fuel and kerosene produced by the taxpayer in the United States and used (or sold for use) in an aircraft as part of the taxpayer's trade or business
defined_terms.Sustainable Aviation Fuel: liquid fuel that meets certain technical requirements, is not derived from coprocessing an applicable material with non-biomass feedstock or from palm fatty acid distillates or petroleum, and which has a lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions reduction percentage of at least 50%

impacts.description: Encourages the use of sustainable aviation fuel, potentially leading to a significant reduction in greenhouse gas emissions in the aviation sector. The sector might face higher costs in the short term due to transitioning to environmentally sustainable fuels and ensuring compliance with new fuel regulations and certifications. Yet, these could be offset by the tax credits gained from participating in this scheme.
impacts.estimated_cost: Dependent on the uptake and production of sustainable aviation fuels
impacts.timeline: Effective from December 31, 2022 until December 31, 2024

referenced_sections: Section 211(o)(1)(H) of the Clean Air Act

results.title: CLEAN HYDROGEN
results.content: Section 13204. CLEAN HYDROGEN....(truncated for brevity)...
results.summary: This section amends multiple portions of the Internal Revenue Code to incentivize the production of clean hydrogen. It establishes different credit percentages based on the greenhouse gas emissions rates associated with hydrogen production. It also reduces the tax credit for facilities benefitting from tax-exempt bonds, and places restrictions on facilities that also receive credit under Section 45Q. Additionally, the section terminates the excise tax credit of Section 6426(d)(2) for hydrogen on fuel sold or used after December 31, 2022.
key_points: Creation of a clean hydrogen production credit, with the credit amount calculated based on the number of kilograms of qualified clean hydrogen produced at a qualified production facility within a 10-year period.

Definition of 'clean hydrogen' as hydrogen produced through a process resulting in a lifecycle greenhouse gas emission rate not greater than 4 kilograms of CO2e per kilogram of hydrogen, with additional requirements for its manufacture and usage.
The clean hydrogen tax credit is increased for production facilities meeting wage and apprenticeship requirements.
Facilities receiving credits under Section 45Q will not be eligible for the hydrogen production credit.
Termination of the excise tax credit for hydrogen.

defined_terms.qualified clean hydrogen: Hydrogen produced through a process that results in a lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions rate of not greater than 4 kilograms
defined_terms.qualified clean hydrogen production faci: A facility owned by the taxpayer which produces qualified clean hydrogen, and construction of which begins before January 1, 2033
defined_terms.lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions: Emissions through the point of production as determined under the GREET model developed by Argonne National Laboratory or a successor model.

impacts.description: The creation of a new tax credit for clean hydrogen production will incentivize the use of low-emissions hydrogen production methods, potentially paving the way for clean hydrogen to play a larger role in the energy sector. The impact is significant due to potentially large shifts in method of hydrogen production, and the subsequent effects on greenhouse gas emissions.
impacts.estimated_cost: Varies depending on the scale of clean hydrogen production
impacts.timeline: Effective for hydrogen produced after December 31, 2022, and for facilities the construction of which begins after the date of enactment of this Act. Excise tax credit termination applicable to fuel sold or used after December 31, 2022.

results.title: EXTENSION, INCREASE, AND MODIFICATIONS OF NONBUSINESS ENERGY PROPERTY CREDIT
results.content: Section 13301...
results.summary: This section extends and amends the nonbusiness energy property credit. It extends the credit from December 31, 2021, to December 31, 2032. The credit value is revised to 30% of energy-efficient home improvement costs, and introduces an annual limitation ($1,200) in lieu of the lifetime limitation. It modifies the standards for energy efficiency and the definition of residential energy property expenditures. It also introduces credit for home energy audits, and requirement of a product identification number for properties placed in service after December 31, 2024.
key_points: Extension of the credit from December 31, 2021 to December 31, 2032
Allowance of the credit as per improvements and expenditures made by the taxpayer
Introduction of annual limitations on the credit
Changes regarding standards for energy efficient building components
Modification of the definition of residential energy property expenditures
Introduction of home energy audits and product identification number

defined_terms.home energy audit: An inspection and written report focusing on energy efficiency improvements of a dwelling.
defined_terms.residential energy property expenditures: Expenditures made by the taxpayer for qualified energy property installed on a dwelling unit located in the United States and used as a residence by the taxpayer
defined_terms.qualified energy property: Property meeting highest level of efficiency standards established by the Consortium for Energy Efficiency
defined_terms.qualified product identification number: A unique product identification number assigned by a manufacturer, according to the methodology required by the Secretary

impacts.description: A significant amount of energy efficiency improvements and expenditures covered under this credit. Homeowners will be incentivized to undertake energy efficiency improvements and purchase energy-efficient property. The market for energy-efficient home improvements, residential energy-efficient products, and home energy audit services may experience boosted growth.
impacts.timeline: Effective for property placed in service after December 31, 2022. Timeline varies for certain subsections.

results.title: EXTENSION OF INCENTIVES FOR BIODIESEL, RENEWABLE DIESEL AND ALTERNATIVE FUELS
results.content: Section 13201 (full text here)
results.summary: Section 13201 extends the incentives for production and sales of biodiesel, renewable diesel, and alternative fuels. The extension period for these credits is to December 31, 2024. The section also describes a framework for the submission and payment of credits for fuel sold or used after December 31, 2021.
key_points: The existing credits for biodiesel and renewable diesel are extended till December 31, 2024
The alternative fuel credit is also extended till December 31, 2024
The extensions apply to fuel sold or used after December 31, 2021
The Treasury Secretary is tasked with issuing guidance for a one-time submission of claims, and a 180-day period for the submission of these claims will commence 30 days after this guidance is issued

impacts.description: The extension of these credits incentivizes the continued production and sale of biodiesel, renewable diesel, and alternative fuels. This may drive growth in these sectors and contribute to achieving climate goals. Additionally, the mandated guidance and new process for claim submission might streamline operations, but could also impose administrative costs.
impacts.estimated_cost: Cost is unknown, will depend on level of credit claimed
impacts.timeline: Extensions apply to fuel sold or used after December 31, 2021

results.title: EXTENSION, INCREASE, AND MODIFICATIONS OF NEW ENERGY EFFICIENT HOME CREDIT
results.content: Section 13304 text as provided
results.summary: This section extends the New Energy Efficient Home Credit to December 31, 2032, increases the credit amounts, and updates the requirements for energy savings for eligible constructions. It also introduces a prevailing wage requirement for certain constructions which results in an increased credit.
key_points: The section extends the New Energy Efficient Home Credit to December 31, 2032, from the previous deadline of December 31, 2021.
The credit amount for qualifying residences (single-family homes, manufactured homes, and dwellings in multi-family buildings) is modified.
The section updates the energy saving requirements, replacing existing ones with new, updated standards.
Prevailing wage requirements are introduced. If these requirements are met, the credit amount increases for qualifying residences.
Certain adjustments are made around the adjusted basis of a building in relation to section 42 of the IRS code.

defined_terms.Prevailing wage: Wages at rates not less than the prevailing rates for construction, alteration, or repair of a similar character in the locality where the residence is located as most recently determined by the Secretary of Labor
defined_terms.Zero energy ready home: A dwelling unit certified as a zero energy ready home under the zero energy ready home program of the Department of Energy as in effect on January 1, 2023 (or any successor program determined by the Secretary)

impacts.description: This section can drive significant changes in construction practices, impact the cost of new homes, and potentially lead to job losses if the construction industry cannot meet the new guidelines in a cost-effective way. However, the energy savings may offset some of these costs and reduce the environmental impact of new constructions.
impacts.timeline: Applies to dwelling units acquired after December 31, 2022, but the credit extension applies to dwelling units acquired after December 31, 2021.

results.title: ENERGY EFFICIENT COMMERCIAL BUILDINGS DEDUCTION
results.content: Section 13303. ENERGY EFFICIENT COMMERCIAL BUILDINGS DEDUCTION...(text truncated for brevity)...
results.summary: Section 13303 modifies section 179D of the Internal Revenue Code to provide an increased deduction for energy efficient commercial buildings and introduces greater deductibility for retrofitting old properties to become more energy efficient. The deduction varies depending on the reduction in the building's total annual energy and power costs, with adjustments for projects meeting specified wage and apprenticeship requirements.
key_points: Increases the maximum deduction for energy efficient commercial buildings and retrofit properties
The deductible amount will vary depending on the reduction in a building's total energy and power usage
Expands deduction eligibility to retrofit projects on buildings older than 5 years
Enforces wage and apprenticeship requirements and includes penalties for non-compliance

defined_terms.Applicable dollar value: Amount related to the building's reduction in total annual energy and power costs
defined_terms.Energy use intensity: The annualized, measured site energy use intensity
defined_terms.Qualified retrofit plan: A written plan specifying modifications to a building expected to reduce the building's energy use by 25% or more
defined_terms.Energy efficient building retrofit prope: Depreciable property installed as part of a building's interior lighting systems, heating, cooling, ventilation, hot water systems, or building envelope
defined_terms.Qualified building: Building located in the U.S., originally placed in service not less than 5 years before the retrofit project begins
defined_terms.Qualified professional: Licensed architect or engineer meeting additional requirements set by the Secretary

impacts.description: Real estate developers, builders, building companies, and energy saving contractors will have an increased incentive to build and retrofit old buildings to become more energy efficient. The enhanced deduction benefits will boost pay equity in construction and architectural engineering industries by enforcing prevailing wage and apprenticeship requirements.

results.title: CREDIT FOR PREVIOUSLY-OWNED CLEAN VEHICLES
results.content: Section 13402. CREDIT FOR PREVIOUSLY-OWNED CLEAN VEHICLES....
results.summary: This section introduces a financial credit for individuals who purchase previously-owned clean vehicles. The credit amount is the lesser of $4,000 or 30% of the sale price. Certain income limitations are defined, and criteria for a qualified previously-owned vehicle are described. The section is applicable to vehicles acquired after December 31, 2022.
key_points: Tax credit is for individuals buying previously-owned clean vehicles.
Credit amount is lesser of $4,000 or 30% of sale price.
Credit availability depends on taxpayers' adjusted gross income.
Applicable to vehicles purchased after December 31, 2022.

defined_terms.previously-owned clean vehicle: A motor vehicle, model year of which is at least 2 years earlier than the calendar year in which the taxpayer acquires such vehicle, and which meets other criteria.
defined_terms.qualified sale: A sale of a motor vehicle by a dealer, for a price which does not exceed $25,000, and which is the first transfer since the date of the enactment of this section to a qualified buyer.
defined_terms.qualified buyer: An individual who purchases the vehicle for use and not for resale, with no deduction allowable with respect to another taxpayer under section 151, and who has not been allowed a credit under this section for any sale during the 3-year period ending on the date of the sale of such vehicle.

impacts.description: This credit can stimulate the secondhand clean vehicles market, increase the adoption of clean vehicles among lower-income households, and lower CO2 emissions.

results.title: CLEAN VEHICLE CREDIT
results.content: Section 13401. CLEAN VEHICLE CREDIT... (omitted for brevity)
results.summary: This section amends Section 30D to modify and extend clean vehicle credits. Removal of limits on the number of vehicles eligible for credit per manufacturer.
Transfer provisions are available from consumer to dealer under certain conditions.
Termination date of December 31, 2032 for these credits.
The Secretary of Treasury to provide advanced payments to registered dealers, with an increase of 6.0445% in fiscal year 2023 and thereafter for those credits that are treated as direct spending.

defined_terms.Eligible Entity: Any dealer which fulfills the specified criteria, including registration, disclosure requirements, making payments to the taxpayer, and maintaining compliance with the incentive regulation
defined_terms.Clean: Replacing the term 'qualified plug-in electric drive motor'

impacts.description: May stimulate further domestic production of critical minerals and battery components due to increased demand from automotive manufacturers.

results.title: EXTENSION OF THE ADVANCED ENERGY PROJECT CREDIT
results.content:
Section 13501. EXTENSION OF THE ADVANCED ENERGY PROJECT CREDIT.

(a) Extension of Credit.--Section 48C is amended by ...

Expands qualifying projects to include those reducing carbon, processing critical materials, and using new industrial technologies.

results.title: ALTERNATIVE FUEL REFUELING PROPERTY CREDIT

results.title: CLEAN FUEL PRODUCTION CREDIT

results.title: REINSTATEMENT OF LIMITATION RULES FOR DEDUCTION FOR STATE AND LOCAL, ETC., TAXES; EXTENSION OF LIMITATION ON EXCESS BUSINESS LOSSES OF NONCORPORATE TAXPAYERS
results.content:
Section 13903. REINSTATEMENT OF LIMITATION RULES FOR DEDUCTION FOR STATE

AND LOCAL, ETC., TAXES; EXTENSION OF LIMITATION ON EXCESS BUSINESS LOSSES OF NONCORPORATE TAXPAYERS. (a) Reinstatement of Limitation Rules for Deduction for State and Local, etc., Taxes.-- (1) In general.--Section 164(b)(6), as amended by section 13904, is further amended-- (A) in the heading, by striking ``2026'' and inserting ``2025'', and (B) by striking ``2027'' and inserting ``2026''. (2) Effective date.--The amendments made by this subsection shall apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2022. (b) Extension of Limitation on Excess Business Losses of Noncorporate Taxpayers.-- (1) In general.--Section 461(l)(1) is amended by striking ``January 1, 2027'' each place it appears and inserting ``January 1, 2029''. (2) Effective date.--The amendments made by this subsection shall apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2026.
results.summary: This section amends the limitations on deductions for state and local taxes and extensions on the limitation on excess business losses for non-corporate taxpayers. The time frame for the limitations on deductions for state taxes is reduced by one year, moving from 2027 to 2026. Meanwhile, the limits on excess business losses for non-corporate taxpayers extends two more years to January 1, 2029.
key_points: The section amends the timeframe for limitations on deductions for state and local taxes, reducing it from 2027 to 2026.
The limitations on excess business losses for non-corporate taxpayers are extended by two years to January 1, 2029.

impacts.description: This section has a significant effect on non-corporate taxpayers, specifically those who claim deductions for state and local taxes and those who have excess business losses. These taxpayers will face changes in the timeframe during which they can claim such deductions or loss limitations. These changes can impact their overall tax liabilities.
impacts.timeline: The amendments apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2022 for the deduction for state and local taxes, and after December 31, 2026 for excess business losses.

results.title: ROYALTIES ON ALL EXTRACTED METHANE

Section 50263. ROYALTIES ON ALL EXTRACTED METHANE.

(a) In General.--For all leases issued after the date of enactment of this Act, except as provided in subsection (b), royalties paid for gas produced from Federal land and on the outer Continental Shelf shall be assessed on all gas produced, including all gas that is consumed or lost by venting, flaring, or negligent releases through any equipment during upstream operations. (b) Exception.--Subsection (a) shall not apply with respect to-- (1) gas vented or flared for not longer than 48 hours in an emergency situation that poses a danger to human health, safety, or the environment; (2) gas used or consumed within the area of the lease, unit, or communitized area for the benefit of the lease, unit, or communitized area; or (3) gas that is unavoidably lost.
results.summary: This section introduces the payment of royalties on all gas produced from Federal land and on the outer Continental Shelf. These royalties are assessed not only on gas sold but also on gas consumed or lost due to venting, flaring, or negligent releases. Exceptions are made for emergency situations, gas used within the lease area for a lease's benefit, or gas unavoidably lost.

Exceptions are made for emergency situations, gas used within the lease, or gas unavoidably lost.

(a) In General.--In addition to amounts otherwise available, there is appropriated to the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency for fiscal year 2022, out of any money in the Treasury not otherwise appropriated, $5,000,000, to remain available until September 30, 2031, for the Environmental Protection Agency to support-- (1) enhanced standardization and transparency of corporate climate action commitments and plans to reduce greenhouse gas emissions; (2) enhanced transparency regarding progress toward meeting such commitments and implementing such plans; and (3) progress toward meeting such commitments and implementing such plans. (b) Definition of Greenhouse Gas.--In this section, the term ``greenhouse gas'' means the air pollutants carbon dioxide, hydrofluorocarbons, methane, nitrous oxide, perfluorocarbons, and sulfur hexafluoride.
results.summary: Section 60111 appropriates $5,000,000 for the fiscal year 2022 to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), available until September 30, 2031. The funding is to enhance the standardization and transparency of corporate commitments and plans to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, as well as monitor progress towards meeting these commitments and plans.
key_points: Appropriation of $5,000,000 available until September 30, 2031, to the EPA.
Aims to enhance standardization and transparency of corporate climate action commitments and plans.
Focuses on monitoring progress towards meeting these commitments and implementing these plans.
Defines 'Greenhouse Gas' as carbon dioxide, hydrofluorocarbons, methane, nitrous oxide, perfluorocarbons, and sulfur hexafluoride.

impacts.description: Corporations will be subject to enhanced scrutiny regarding their greenhouse gas emission reduction commitments and actions. This may lead to additional reporting requirements and adjustments to meet standardized regulations.
impacts.timeline: Funding available until September 30, 2031

impacts.description: By standardizing and increasing transparency around corporate greenhouse gas emission reduction commitments and actions, this legislation encourages mitigation of climate change impacts.
impacts.timeline: Long-term impact tracking emission commitments and plans until September 30, 2031

results.title: ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY EFFICIENT, ACCURATE, AND TIMELY REVIEWS
results.content:
Section 60115. ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY EFFICIENT, ACCURATE, AND

TIMELY REVIEWS. In addition to amounts otherwise available, there is appropriated to the Environmental Protection Agency for fiscal year 2022, out of any money in the Treasury not otherwise appropriated, $40,000,000, to remain available until September 30, 2026, to provide for the development of efficient, accurate, and timely reviews for permitting and approval processes through the hiring and training of personnel, the development of programmatic documents, the procurement of technical or scientific services for reviews, the development of environmental data or information systems, stakeholder and community engagement, the purchase of new equipment for environmental analysis, and the development of geographic information systems and other analysis tools, techniques, and guidance to improve agency transparency, accountability, and public engagement.
results.summary: Section 60115 appropriates $40,000,000 to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) for fiscal year 2022, to enhance the efficiency, accuracy, and timeliness of their review processes. The funds, available until September 30, 2026, will be used to hire and train personnel, develop documents, procure services, enhance data systems, engage with stakeholders, purchase new equipment, and devise tools and techniques. The objective is to improve the EPA's transparency, accountability, and public engagement.
key_points: Fiscal year 2022 appropriation of $40,000,000 to the EPA
Funds to be used to enhance the EPA's review processes
Areas of focus include personnel training, service procurement, data system enhancement, stakeholder engagement, and equipment procurement
Objective is to improve the EPA's transparency, accountability, and public engagement

impacts.description: Enhancements to the EPA's review processes could increase the efficiency and accuracy of environmental reviews, benefiting the overall environmental sector. However, the impact will depend on the specifics of how these funds are used.
impacts.timeline: Funds available until September 30, 2026

results.title: ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT RECOVERY PLANS
results.content:
Section 60301. ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT RECOVERY PLANS.

In addition to amounts otherwise available, there is appropriated to the United States Fish and Wildlife Service for fiscal year 2022, out of any money in the Treasury not otherwise appropriated, $125,000,000, to remain available until expended, for the purposes of developing and implementing recovery plans under paragraphs (1), (3), and (4) of subsection (f) of section 4 of the Endangered Species Act of 1973 (16 U.S.C. 1533(f)).
results.summary: Section 60301 appropriates $125,000,000 to the United States Fish and Wildlife Service for fiscal year 2022, for developing and implementing recovery plans as per the Endangered Species Act of 1973. The funds will cover plans outlined in subsection (f) of section 4 of the mentioned act.
key_points: Allocation of $125,000,000 to the United States Fish and Wildlife Service for fiscal year 2022.
Funds to aid the development and implementation of recovery plans.
Covers plans outlined in the Endangered Species Act of 1973's section 4, subsection (f).
Funds will remain available until they are fully expended.

impacts.description: The allocated funding will boost the efforts of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service in developing and implementing recovery plans for endangered species, significantly impacting conservation efforts.
impacts.timeline: Funding allocated for fiscal year 2022 and available until expended
affected_groups: United States Fish and Wildlife Service

results.title: ENVIRONMENTAL AND CLIMATE DATA COLLECTION
results.content: In addition to amounts otherwise available, there is appropriated to the Chair of the Council on Environmental Quality for fiscal year 2022, out of any money in the Treasury not otherwise appropriated, $32,500,000, to remain available until September 30, 2026-- (1) to support data collection efforts relating to-- (A) disproportionate negative environmental harms and climate impacts; and (B) cumulative impacts of pollution and temperature rise; (2) to establish, expand, and maintain efforts to track disproportionate burdens and cumulative impacts and provide academic and workforce support for analytics and informatics infrastructure and data collection systems; and (3) to support efforts to ensure that any mapping or screening tool is accessible to community-based organizations and community members.
results.summary: The section allocates $32,500,000 in additional funding to the Chair of the Council on Environmental Quality for the purpose of supporting data collection initiatives and the development of tracking methods for environmental impacts. This appropriation is particularly focused on addressing disproportionate environmental and climate burdens. The funds will be used until September 30, 2026.
key_points: Allocation of $32,500,000 to support environmental data collection efforts.
The funding focuses on addressing disproportionate environmental harms and climate impacts, as well as the cumulative impacts of pollution and temperature rise.
Efforts to establish, expand, and maintain systems to track disproportionate burdens and cumulative impacts will be accelerated.
There will be support for ensuring that mapping or screening tool is accessible to community-based organizations and local community members.

impacts.description: The funding will result in more effective tracking and understanding of environmental burdens and climate impacts. Access to relevant information will be enhanced, particularly for community-based organizations and community members.
impacts.timeline: Funds to be utilized from fiscal year 2022 until September 30, 2026.

results.title: GENERAL SERVICES ADMINISTRATION EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES
results.content:
Section 60504. GENERAL SERVICES ADMINISTRATION EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES.

In addition to amounts otherwise available, there is appropriated to the Administrator of General Services for fiscal year 2022, out of any money in the Treasury not otherwise appropriated, $975,000,000, to remain available until September 30, 2026, to be deposited in the Federal Buildings Fund established under section 592 of title 40, United States Code, for emerging and sustainable technologies, and related sustainability and environmental programs.
results.summary: Section 60504 appropriates $975,000,000 to the Administrator of General Services for fiscal year 2022. The funds, available till September 30, 2026, will be used for emerging and sustainable technologies, and related sustainability and environmental programs.
key_points: An appropriation of $975,000,000 is made to the Administrator of General Services.
The funds are to be used for emerging and sustainable technologies and associated sustainability and environmental programs.

impacts.description: The provision provides significant funding for emerging tech and sustainable initiatives, supporting development and implementation. Bureaucracies, clean tech innovators, and environmental programs can anticipate direct benefits.
impacts.timeline: Funds available from fiscal year 2022 until September 30, 2026
